mediacapture-fromelement.description: API to capture Real-Time video and audio from a DOM element, such as a `<video>`, `<audio>`, or `<canvas>` element via the `captureStream` method, in the form of a `MediaStream`

notes_by_num.1: Does not support capture from `<video>`/`<audio>`
notes_by_num.2: Capture from `<video>`/`<audio>` can be enabled via the Experimental Web Platform Features flag.

mediarecorder.title: MediaRecorder API
mediarecorder.description: The MediaRecorder API (MediaStream Recording) aims to provide a really simple mechanism by which developers can record media streams from the user's input devices and instantly use them in web apps, rather than having to perform manual encoding operations on raw PCM data, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the experimental Web Platform features flag. Does not support audio recording, only video.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu.
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled using the Advanced > Experimental Features menu.

mediasource.title: Media Source Extensions
mediasource.description: API allowing media data to be accessed from HTML `video` and `audio` elements.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the `media.mediasource.enabled` flag to be enabled, support is limited to a whitelist including the YouTube, Netflix, and Dailymotion websites
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 refers to only working in Windows 8+
notes_by_num.3: Due to compatibility issues, MediaSource Extensions are currently disabled by default in Samsung Internet.

menu.title: Context menu item (menuitem element)
menu.description: Method of defining a context menu item, now deprecated and [removed from the HTML specification](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2730).

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to being limited to context menus, not toolbar menus.
notes_by_num.2: Context menus supported in Chromium under the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.3: Context menus with a non-compliant syntax (`type=popup`) supported in Chromium under the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.4: Nested menus are not supported
notes_by_num.5: Context menus supported in Chromium with the "enable-blink-features=ContextMenu" command line flag

meta-theme-color.title: theme-color Meta Tag
meta-theme-color.description: Meta tag to define a suggested color that browsers should use to customize the display of the page or of the surrounding user interface.
meta-theme-color.notes: Also supported in the (now discontinued) Firefox OS, but not Firefox for other OSes.

meter.title: meter element
meter.description: Method of indicating the current level of a gauge.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Examples of progress and meter elements

midi.title: Web MIDI API
midi.description: The Web MIDI API specification defines a means for web developers to enumerate, manipulate and access MIDI devices

minmaxwh.title: CSS min/max-width/height
minmaxwh.description: Method of setting a minimum or maximum width or height to an element.

notes_by_num.1: IE7 does not support `inherit` as a value on any of these properties.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 has some bugs with `max-width`/`height` combined with `overflow: auto`/`scroll`.

mp3.title: MP3 audio format
mp3.notes: Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Firefox refers to being limited to certain operating systems.

mpeg-dash.title: Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (MPEG-DASH)
mpeg-dash.description: HTTP-based media streaming communications protocol, an alternative to HTTP Live Streaming (HLS).
mpeg-dash.notes: DASH can be used with a JavaScript library in browsers that doesn't support it natively as long as they support [Media Source Extensions](/#feat=mediasource).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `media.dash.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only WebM video is supported.

mpeg4.title: MPEG-4/H.264 video format

links.title: Firefox extension allowing support in Win7

mpeg4.notes:
Firefox supports H.264 on Windows 7 and later since version 21. Firefox supports H.264 on Linux since version 26 if the appropriate gstreamer plug-ins are installed.

Partial support for older Firefox versions refers to the lack of support in OS X & some non-Android Linux platforms.

notes_by_num.1: The Android 2.3 browser requires [specific handling](https://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to play videos.
notes_by_num.2: Partial supports refers to the lack of hardware acceleration.

multibackgrounds.title: CSS3 Multiple backgrounds
multibackgrounds.description: Method of using multiple images as a background

multicolumn.title: CSS3 Multiple column layout
multicolumn.description: Method of flowing information in multiple columns

links.title: Chrome platform status for CSS column-fill

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting the `break-before`, `break-after`, and `break-inside` properties. WebKit- and Blink-based browsers do have equivalent support for the non-standard `-webkit-column-break-*` properties to accomplish the same result (but only the `auto` and `always` values). Firefox does not support `break-*` but does support the now-obsolute `page-break-*` properties in the paging (printing) context.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `column-fill` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not supporting the `avoid-column`, `column`, and `avoid` (in the column context) values for the properties `break-before`, `break-after`, and `break-inside`.

mutation-events.title: Mutation events
mutation-events.description: Deprecated mechanism for listening to changes made to the DOM, replaced by Mutation Observers.
mutation-events.notes: See also support for [Mutation Observer](https://caniuse.com/#feat=mutationobserver), which replaces mutation events and does not have the same performance drawbacks.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `DOMAttrModified`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `DOMNodeInsertedIntoDocument` & `DOMNodeRemovedFromDocument`

mutationobserver.title: Mutation Observer
mutationobserver.description: Method for observing and reacting to changes to the DOM. Replaces MutationEvents, which is deprecated.
mutationobserver.notes: When changing the `innerHTML` content of a node containing a single `CharacterData` node, resulting in a single-but-different `CharacterData` child node, WebKit browsers consider this a `characterData` mutation of the child `CharacterData` node, while other browsers consider it a `childList` mutation of the parent node.

namevalue-storage.title: Web Storage - name/value pairs
namevalue-storage.description: Method of storing data locally like cookies, but for larger amounts of data (sessionStorage and localStorage, used to fall under HTML5).

nav-timing.title: Navigation Timing API
nav-timing.description: API for accessing timing information related to navigation and elements.
nav-timing.notes: Removed in iOS 8.1 due to poor performance.

netinfo.title: Network Information API
netinfo.description: The Network Information API enables web applications to access information about the network connection in use by the device. Accessed via `navigator.connection`
netinfo.notes: In Chrome the API is enabled on Android only, support for other platforms [is coming](https://docs.google.com/a/chromium.org/document/d/1LTk9uVMGi4kurzcF5ellsAJReTF31fFJMHrQwSVtBjc/) . Support is also available on [Firefox OS](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960426).

notes_by_num.1: Supports only the `navigator.connection.type` value which doesn't match the latest spec. [see details](https://www.davidbcalhoun.com/2010/optimizing-based-on-connection-speed-using-navigator.connection-on-android-2.2-/)
notes_by_num.2: Only supports the `type` value.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `type` and `downlinkMax` values.
notes_by_num.4: Only supports the `downlink`, `effectiveType` & `rtt` values.

notifications.title: Web Notifications
notifications.description: Method of alerting the user outside of a web page by displaying notifications (that do not require interaction by the user).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in `about:flags`
notes_by_num.2: Supports notifications via the [Push API](https://caniuse.com/#feat=push-api) but not the Web Notifications API.
notes_by_num.3: Chrome for Android requires the call to be made with a [service worker registration](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Notifications_API#Service_worker_additions)

object-entries.title: Object.entries
object-entries.description: The `Object.entries()` method creates a multi-dimensional array of key value pairs from the given object.

object-fit.title: CSS3 object-fit/object-position
object-fit.description: Method of specifying how an object (image or video) should fit inside its box. object-fit options include "contain" (fit according to aspect ratio), "fill" (stretches object to fill) and "cover" (overflows box but maintains ratio), where object-position allows the object to be repositioned like background-image does.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Safari refers to support for `object-fit` but not `object-position`.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Edge refers to `object-fit` only supporting `` ([see this comment](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/13603873/#comment-0))

object-observe.title: Object.observe data binding
object-observe.description: Method for data binding, a now-withdrawn ECMAScript 7 proposal
object-observe.notes: Support in Blink-based browsers is expected to be removed in future versions.

object-values.title: Object.values method
object-values.description: The `Object.values()` method returns an array of a given object's own enumerable property values.

objectrtc.title: Object RTC (ORTC) API for WebRTC
objectrtc.description: Enables mobile endpoints to talk to servers and web browsers with Real-Time Communications (RTC) capabilities via native and simple JavaScript APIs

links.title: Bringing Interoperable Real-Time Communications to the Web

objectrtc.notes: ORTC is often dubbed WebRTC 1.1. It is possible to make ORTC communicate with WebRTC 1.0 endpoints. See [WebRTC 1.0](https://caniuse.com/#feat=rtcpeerconnection) for support details for that API.

offline-apps.title: Offline web applications
offline-apps.description: Now deprecated method of defining web page files to be cached using a cache manifest file, allowing them to work offline on subsequent visits to the page.
offline-apps.notes: This technology is being deprecated in favor of [Service Workers](https://caniuse.com/#feat=serviceworkers)

offscreencanvas.title: OffscreenCanvas
offscreencanvas.description: OffscreenCanvas allows canvas drawing to occur with no connection to the DOM and can be used inside workers.

links.title: WebGL off the main thread - Mozilla Hacks article

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `gfx.offscreencanvas.enabled` flag. Currently only supports WebGL contexts, not 2D.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `Experimental canvas features` flag

ogg-vorbis.title: Ogg Vorbis audio format
ogg-vorbis.description: Vorbis is a free and open source audio format, most commonly used with the Ogg container.
ogg-vorbis.notes: Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

ol-reversed.title: Reversed attribute of ordered lists
ol-reversed.description: This attribute makes an ordered list number its items in descending order (large to small), instead of ascending order (small to large; the default). The order that the list items are displayed in is not affected.

links.title: HTML5 Doctor article on <ol> element attributes (including reversed)
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

once-event-listener.title: "once" event listener option
once-event-listener.description: Causes an event listener to be automatically removed after it gets invoked, so that it only gets invoked once. Similar to jQuery's `$.one()` feature.

links.title: Chromium Issue 615384: Support "once" event listener option
MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

online-status.title: Online/offline status
online-status.description: Events to indicate when the user's connected (`online` and `offline` events) and the `navigator.onLine` property to see current status.
online-status.notes:
"online" does not always mean connection to the internet, it can also just mean connection to some network.

Early versions of Chrome and Safari always reported "true" for `navigator.onLine`

notes_by_num.0: Safari 7.0 supports only the event listener on `window`, and not on `document.body`
notes_by_num.1: Seems to support `navigator.onLine` but not `online`/`offline` events.
notes_by_num.2: IE8 only supports the `online`/`offline` events on `document.body`, rather than `window`.
notes_by_num.3: Desktop Firefox responds to the status of its "Work Offline" mode. If not in that mode, `navigator.onLine` is always `true`, regardless of the actual network connectivity status. [See bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=654579) for details.

opus.title: Opus
opus.description: Royalty-free open audio codec by IETF, which incorporated SILK from Skype and CELT from Xiph.org, to serve higher sound quality and lower latency at the same bitrate.

links.title: Google's statement about the use of VP8 and Opus codec for WebRTC standard
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

opus.notes:
Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

For Opera the Linux version may be able to play it when the GStreamer module is up to date and the served mime-type is 'audio/ogg'.

notes_by_num.1: Supported only when packaged in a CAF file and on macOS High Sierra/iOS 11 or later.

orientation-sensor.title: Orientation Sensor
orientation-sensor.description: Defines a base orientation sensor interface and concrete sensor subclasses to monitor the device’s physical orientation in relation to a stationary three dimensional Cartesian coordinate system.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Generic Sensor" experimental flag in `about:flags`

outline.title: CSS outline properties
outline.description: The CSS outline properties draw a border around an element that does not affect layout, making it ideal for highlighting. This covers the `outline` shorthand, as well as `outline-width`, `outline-style`, `outline-color` and `outline-offset`.

links.title: CSS Basic User Interface Module Level 3

outline.notes: Firefox also supports the non-standard `-moz-outline-radius` property that acts similar to `border-radius`.

notes_by_num.1: Also supports the value of `invert` for `outline-color`. (support of this value is optional for browsers)
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `outline-offset`.

pad-start-end.title: String.prototype.padStart(), String.prototype.padEnd()
pad-start-end.description: The `padStart()` and `padEnd()` methods pad the current string with a given string (eventually repeated) so that the resulting string reaches a given length. The pad is applied from the start (left) of the current string for `padStart()`, and applied from the end (right) of the current string for `padEnd()`.

page-transition-events.title: PageTransitionEvent
page-transition-events.description: Fired at the Window when the page's entry in the session history stops being the current entry. Includes the `pageshow` and `pagehide` events.

pagevisibility.title: Page Visibility
pagevisibility.description: JavaScript API for determining whether a document is visible on the display

passive-event-listener.title: Passive event listeners
passive-event-listener.description: Event listeners created with the `passive: true` option cannot cancel (`preventDefault()`) the events they receive. Primarily intended to be used with touch events and `wheel` events. Since they cannot prevent scrolls, passive event listeners allow the browser to perform optimizations that result in smoother scrolling.

links.title: Improving scroll performance with passive event listeners - Google Developers Updates

path2d.title: Path2D
path2d.description: Allows path objects to be declared on 2D canvas surfaces

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `addPath()` method

payment-request.title: Payment Request API
payment-request.description: Payment Request is a new API for the open web that makes checkout flows easier, faster and consistent on shopping sites.

links.title: Bringing easy and fast checkout with Payment Request API
MDN Web Docs - Payment Request API

payment-request.notes: Apple provides an equivalent proprietary API called [Apple Pay JS](https://developer.apple.com/reference/applepayjs/). Google provides a [PaymentRequest wrapper for Apple Pay JS](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/appr-wrapper).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Payments API" flag
notes_by_num.3: Apple's proprietary implementation (see above)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "[Web Payments API](chrome://flags/#web-payments)" flag
notes_by_num.5: Unlike Desktop Chrome, support has been in Chrome for Android since version 53.
notes_by_num.6: Can be enabled via the `dom.payments.request.enabled` flag in "about:config" flag since 55.
notes_by_num.8: Disabled by default in Nightly. To enable, go to "about:config" and set "dom.payments.request.enabled" to true, and "dom.payments.request.supportedRegions" to "US,CA".

permissions-api.title: Permissions API
permissions-api.description: High-level JavaScript API for checking and requesting permissions

picture.title: Picture element
picture.description: A responsive images method to control which image resource a user agent presents to a user, based on resolution, media query and/or support for a particular image format

links.title: Picturefill - polyfill for picture, srcset, sizes, and more

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Enabled in Opera through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference dom.image.picture.enable to true

picture-in-picture.title: Picture-in-Picture
picture-in-picture.description: Allows websites to create a floating video window that is always on top of other windows so that users may continue consuming media while they interact with other sites or applications on their device.

links.title: Opera equivalent Video Pop Out feature

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox Nightly only via the `media.videocontrols.picture-in-picture.enabled` pref in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Chrome via the `#enable-picture-in-picture` & `#enable-surfaces-for-videos` flags in `chrome://flags`.
notes_by_num.3: Apple provides an equivalent proprietary API for Picture-in-Picture. Only macOS 10.12 Sierra & iOS 9 and newer support this API.
notes_by_num.4: Opera provides an equivalent proprietary feature named Video Pop Out, which allows users to use Picture-in-Picture mode for all playing videos.
notes_by_num.5: Automatically plays fullscreen videos in Picture-in-Picture mode after user hits Home Screen button. Only Android 8.0 Oreo and newer provide appropriate API for Picture-in-Picture.

ping.title: Ping attribute
ping.description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should send a ping request the resource the attribute points to.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Element ping attribute

ping.notes: While still in the WHATWG specification, this feature was removed from the W3C HTML5 specification in 2010.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default for [privacy reasons](http://kb.mozillazine.org/Browser.send_pings). Can be enabled via the `browser.send_pings` flag.

png-alpha.title: PNG alpha transparency
png-alpha.notes: IE6 does support full transparency in 8-bit PNGs, which can sometimes be an alternative to 24-bit PNGs.

pointer.title: Pointer events
pointer.description: This specification integrates various inputs from mice, touchscreens, and pens, making separate implementations no longer necessary and authoring for cross-device pointers easier. Not to be mistaken with the unrelated "pointer-events" CSS property.

links.title: Implementation of Pointer Events in IE10
Hand.js, the polyfill for browsers only supporting Touch Events

pointer.notes: Firefox, starting with version 28, provides the 'dom.w3c_pointer_events.enabled' flag to support this specification.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers the lack of pointerenter and pointerleave events.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox support is disabled by default and [only supports mouse input](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2015/08/pointer-events-now-in-firefox-nightly/). On Windows only, touch can be enabled with the `layers.async-pan-zoom.enabled` and `dom.w3c_touch_events.enabled` flags
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled with the `#enable-pointer-events` flag.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled under the `Experimental Features` menu.

pointer-events.title: CSS pointer-events (for HTML)
pointer-events.description: This CSS property, when set to "none" allows elements to not receive hover/click events, instead the event will occur on anything behind it.
pointer-events.notes: Already part of the SVG specification, and all SVG-supporting browsers appear to support the property on SVG elements.

pointerlock.title: Pointer Lock API
pointerlock.description: API that provides access to raw mouse movement data. This is done by ignoring boundaries resulting from screen edges where the cursor can't go beyond, providing proper control for first person or real time strategy games.

prefers-color-scheme.title: prefers-color-scheme media query
prefers-color-scheme.description: Media query to detect if the user has set their system to use a light or dark color theme.
prefers-color-scheme.notes:
Support will also depend on whether or not the OS has support for a light/dark theme preference.

Briefly known as `prefers-dark-interface` in earlier builds of Safari TP.

prefers-reduced-motion.title: prefers-reduced-motion media query
prefers-reduced-motion.description: CSS media query based on a user preference for preferring reduced motion (animation, etc).

notes_by_num.1: Currently expected to land in Firefox for Windows and Linux in Firefox 63, for MacOS it might be delayed to Firefox 64.

progress.title: progress element
progress.description: Method of indicating a progress state.

links.title: Examples of progress and meter elements

notes_by_num.1: iOS Safari does not support "indeterminate" <progress> elements.

promise-finally.title: Promise.prototype.finally
promise-finally.description: When the promise is settled, whether fulfilled or rejected, the specified callback function is executed.

promises.title: Promises
promises.description: A promise represents the eventual result of an asynchronous operation.

links.title: JavaScript Promises: There and back again - HTML5 Rocks

proximity.title: Proximity API
proximity.description: Defines events that provide information about the distance between a device and an object, as measured by a proximity sensor.

proxy.title: Proxy object
proxy.description: The Proxy object allows custom behavior to be defined for fundamental operations. Useful for logging, profiling, object visualization, etc.

publickeypinning.title: Public Key Pinning
publickeypinning.description: Declare that a website's HTTPS certificate should only be treated as valid if the public key is contained in a specified list to prevent MITM attacks that use valid CA-issued certificates.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Public Key Pinning

publickeypinning.notes:
The HTTP header syntax is 'Public-Key-Pins: pin-sha256="base64=="; max-age=expireTime [; includeSubdomains][; report-uri="reportURI"]'.

Support in Chrome was [deprecated](https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!msg/blink-dev/he9tr7p3rZ8/eNMwKPmUBAAJ) and [removed](https://blog.chromium.org/2018/12/chrome-72-beta-public-class-fields-user.html?m=1).

push-api.title: Push API
push-api.description: API to allow messages to be pushed from a server to a browser, even when the site isn't focused or even open in the browser.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting `PushEvent.data` and `PushMessageData`
notes_by_num.2: Requires full browser to be running to receive messages
notes_by_num.3: Safari supports a custom implementation https://developer.apple.com/notifications/safari-push-notifications/. WWDC video by apple : https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2013/614/
notes_by_num.4: Disabled on Firefox ESR, but can be re-enabled with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` and `dom.push.enabled` flags

queryselector.title: querySelector/querySelectorAll
queryselector.description: Method of accessing DOM elements using CSS selectors

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE8 is due to being limited to [CSS 2.1 selectors](/#feat=css-sel2) and a small subset of [CSS 3 selectors](/#feat=css-sel3) (see notes there). Additionally, it will have trouble with selectors including unrecognized tags (for example HTML5 ones).

readonly-attr.title: readonly attribute of input and textarea elements
readonly-attr.description: Makes the form control non-editable. Unlike the `disabled` attribute, `readonly` form controls are still included in form submissions and the user can still select (but not edit) their value text.

links.title: WHATWG HTML specification for the readonly attribute of the `<textarea>` element

notes_by_num.1: Readonly inputs of type `datetime-local`, `date`, `month`, and `week` can still be edited by pressing the Up or Down arrow keys on the keyboard while the input is focused.
notes_by_num.2: Text cannot be selected directly, but is possible by first selecting any text around the field.

referrer-policy.title: Referrer Policy
referrer-policy.description: Allow control of HTTP referrers via the referrer meta tag.

links.title: A new security header: Referrer Policy

notes_by_num.1: Supports an [older draft](https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Meta_referrer) of the specification with `never`, `always`, `origin` & `default` values.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome does not support `same-origin`, `strict-origin`, or `strict-origin-when-cross-origin` values ([issue 627968](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=627968))

registerprotocolhandler.title: Custom protocol handling
registerprotocolhandler.description: Method of allowing a webpage to handle a given protocol using `navigator.registerProtocolHandler`. This allows certain URLs to be opened by a given web application, for example `mailto:` addresses can be opened by a webmail client.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Register protocol handler

notes_by_num.1: Supports protocols `mailto`, `mms`, `nntp`, `rtsp`, and `webcal` but requires custom protocols to start with `web+`

rel-noopener.title: rel=noopener
rel-noopener.description: Ensure new browsing contexts are opened without a useful `window.opener`

rel-noreferrer.title: Link type "noreferrer"
rel-noreferrer.description: Links with `rel="noreferrer"` set do not send the request's "referrer" header. This prevents the destination site from seeing what URL the user came from.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE11 in later versions of Windows 10 (creators update).

rellist.title: relList (DOMTokenList)
rellist.description: Method of easily manipulating rel attribute values on elements, using the DOMTokenList object (similar to classList).

notes_by_num.1: Support for relList on link but not anchor elements

rem.title: rem (root em) units
rem.description: Type of unit similar to `em`, but relative only to the root element, not any parent element. Thus compounding does not occur as it does with `em` units.

notes_by_num.1: IE 9 & IE 10 do not support `rem` units when used in the `font` shorthand property (the entire declaration is ignored) or when used on pseudo elements.
notes_by_num.2: iOS Safari 5.0-5.1 support `rem` but not in combination with media queries.

requestanimationframe.title: requestAnimationFrame
requestanimationframe.description: API allowing a more efficient way of running script-based animation, compared to traditional methods using timeouts. Also covers support for `cancelAnimationFrame`

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking `cancelAnimationFrame` support.
notes_by_num.2: Supports `webkitCancelRequestAnimationFrame` rather than `webkitCancelAnimationFrame`.

requestidlecallback.title: requestIdleCallback
requestidlecallback.description: API allowing the execution of JavaScript to be queued to run in idle browser time, either at the end of a frame or when the user is inactive. Also covers support for `cancelIdleCallback`. The API has similarities with `requestAnimationFrame`.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `dom.requestIdleCallback.enabled` flag

resizeobserver.title: Resize Observer
resizeobserver.description: Method for observing and reacting to changes to sizes of DOM elements.

links.title: Polyfill based on latest specification which includes support for observer options

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

resource-timing.title: Resource Timing
resource-timing.description: Method to help web developers to collect complete timing information related to resources on a document.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.enable_resource_timing flag
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OSX 10.12+

rest-parameters.title: Rest parameters
rest-parameters.description: Allows representation of an indefinite number of arguments as an array.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental JavaScript features" flag to be enabled

rtcpeerconnection.title: WebRTC Peer-to-peer connections
rtcpeerconnection.description: Method of allowing two users to communicate directly, browser to browser using the RTCPeerConnection API.

links.title: Plug-in for support in IE & Safari
Introducing WebRTC 1.0 and interoperable real-time communications in Microsoft Edge

rtcpeerconnection.notes: Microsoft also offers a compatible implementation known as [ObjectRTC](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2014/10/27/bringing-interoperable-real-time-communications-to-the-web.aspx). See [Object RTC](https://caniuse.com/#feat=objectrtc) for support details for that API.

notes_by_num.1: BlackBerry 10 recognizes RTCPeerConnection but real support is unconfirmed.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Enable WebRTC 1.0" flag
notes_by_num.3: Edge does not support RTCDataChannel. See [API Catalogue](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/catalog/?q=specName%3Awebrtc)

ruby.title: Ruby annotation
ruby.description: Method of adding pronunciation or other annotations using ruby elements (primarily used in East Asian typography).
ruby.notes: Browsers without native support can still simulate support using CSS. Partial support refers to only supporting basic ruby, may still be missing writing-mode, Complex ruby and CSS3 Ruby.

notes_by_num.1: IE9+ supports [properties](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh772055%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) of an older version of the CSS Ruby specification.

run-in.title: display: run-in
run-in.description: If the run-in box contains a block box, same as block. If a block box follows the run-in box, the run-in box becomes the first inline box of the block box. If an inline box follows, the run-in box becomes a block box.

notes_by_num.1: Not before inline-elements

same-site-cookie-attribute.title: 'SameSite' cookie attribute
same-site-cookie-attribute.description: Same-site cookies ("First-Party-Only" or "First-Party") allow servers to mitigate the risk of CSRF and information leakage attacks by asserting that a particular cookie should only be sent with requests initiated from the same registrable domain.

links.title: Preventing CSRF with the same-site cookie attribute
Mozilla Bug #795346: Add SameSite support for cookies
Mozilla Bug #1286861, includes the patches that landed SameSite support in Firefox
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
MS Edge dev blog: "Previewing support for same-site cookies in Microsoft Edge"

same-site-cookie-attribute.notes: This feature is backwards compatible. Browsers not supporting this feature will simply use the cookie as a regular cookie. There is no need to deliver different cookies to clients.

notes_by_num.1: Not shipped with the inital release but later with the 2018 June security update (Patch Tuesday) to Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer. [More info](https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/Status/issues/616).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support because only supported in IE 11 on Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer, but not in IE 11 on other Windows versions (Windows 7, ...)

screen-orientation.title: Screen Orientation
screen-orientation.description: Provides the ability to read the screen orientation state, to be informed when this state changes, and to be able to lock the screen orientation to a specific state.
screen-orientation.notes: Partial support refers to an [older version](https://www.w3.org/TR/2014/WD-screen-orientation-20140220/) of the draft specification, and the spec has undergone significant changes since, for example renaming the `screen.lockOrientation` method to `screen.orientation.lock`.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on Windows 7.

script-async.title: async attribute for external scripts
script-async.description: The boolean async attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when it's available, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Using script.async = false; to maintain execution order for dynamically-added scripts isn't supported in Safari 5.0

script-defer.title: defer attribute for external scripts
script-defer.description: The boolean defer attribute on script elements allows the external JavaScript file to run when the DOM is loaded, without delaying page load first.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older IE refers to a buggy implementation (see issue).
notes_by_num.2: Deferred scripts may run after DOMContentLoaded - https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=688580

scrollintoview.title: scrollIntoView
scrollintoview.description: The `Element.scrollIntoView()` method scrolls the current element into the visible area of the browser window. Parameters can be provided to set the position inside the visible area as well as whether scrolling should be instant or smooth.

links.title: smooth scroll polyfill : polyfill for smooth behavior option

notes_by_num.1: Supports scrollIntoView with boolean parameter, but not `smooth` behavior option

scrollintoviewifneeded.title: Element.scrollIntoViewIfNeeded()
scrollintoviewifneeded.description: If the element is fully within the visible area of the viewport, it does nothing. Otherwise, the element is scrolled into view. A proprietary variant of the standard `Element.scrollIntoView()` method.

links.title: W3C CSSOM View bug #17152: Support centering an element when scrolling into view.
Shared Dictionary Compression for HTTP at LinkedIn.

selection-api.title: Selection API
selection-api.description: API for accessing selected content of a document, including the `window.getSelection()` method, as well as the `selectstart` & `selectionchange` events on `document`.
selection-api.notes: See also support for the related [DOM range](https://caniuse.com/#feat=dom-range)

notes_by_num.1: Supports `window.getSelection()` but no selection events
notes_by_num.2: Supports selection events, but not `window.getSelection()`
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `selectstart` event
notes_by_num.4: `window.getSelection()` may fail on tapping buttons, as the selection is lost right before the listener code runs.
notes_by_num.5: Selection events are supported behind the `dom.select_events.enabled` flag

server-timing.title: Server Timing
server-timing.description: Mechanism for web developers to annotate network requests with server timing information.

notes_by_num.1: Chrome v60-63: An older version of the API is behind the [Experimental Web Platform features](chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features) flag.
notes_by_num.2: Chrome v64: The current API is behind the [Experimental Web Platform features](chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features) flag.
notes_by_num.3: Safari v12.1+: Supports the Server Timing reporting in the Web Inspector Network tab, but not the JavaScript API

serviceworkers.title: Service Workers
serviceworkers.description: Method that enables applications to take advantage of persistent background processing, including hooks to enable bootstrapping of web applications while offline.
serviceworkers.notes: Details on partial support can be found on [is ServiceWorker Ready?](https://jakearchibald.github.io/isserviceworkerready/)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Available behind the "Enable service workers" flag
notes_by_num.3: Disabled on Firefox ESR, but can be re-enabled with the `dom.serviceWorkers.enabled` flag
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

setimmediate.title: Efficient Script Yielding: setImmediate()
setimmediate.description: Yields control flow without the minimum delays enforced by setTimeout

shadowdom.title: Shadow DOM (deprecated V0 spec)
shadowdom.description: Original V0 version of the Shadow DOM specification. See [Shadow DOM V1](#feat=shadow-domv1) for support for the latest version.

links.title: Google Developers - Shadow DOM v1: self-contained web components

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox behind the `dom.webcomponents.shadowdom.enabled` flag.

shadowdomv1.title: Shadow DOM (V1)
shadowdomv1.description: Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM & CSS.

links.title: Google Developers - Shadow DOM v1: self-contained web components

notes_by_num.1: Certain CSS selectors do not work (`:host > .local-child`) and styling slotted content (`::slotted`) is buggy.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.enabled` preference in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the `dom.webcomponents.shadowdom.enabled` preference in `about:config`.

sharedarraybuffer.title: Shared Array Buffer
sharedarraybuffer.description: Type of ArrayBuffer that can be shared across Workers.

notes_by_num.1: Has support, but was disabled across browsers in January 2018 due to Spectre & Meltdown vulnerabilities.

sharedworkers.title: Shared Web Workers
sharedworkers.description: Method of allowing multiple scripts to communicate with a single web worker.

sni.title: Server Name Indication
sni.description: An extension to the TLS computer networking protocol by which a client indicates which hostname it is attempting to connect to at the start of the handshaking process.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported on Windows Vista or above (not Windows XP)

spdy.title: SPDY protocol
spdy.description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Superseded by HTTP version 2.
spdy.notes:
See also support for [HTTP2](https://caniuse.com/#feat=http2), successor of SPDY.

Chrome will be removing support in 2016 (in favor of HTTP2), other browsers likely to follow.

notes_by_num.1: Deprecated as of macOS Mojave 10.4.4. To be completely removed in a future version of macOS.
notes_by_num.2: Deprecated as of iOS 12.2. To be completely removed in a future version of iOS.

speech-recognition.title: Speech Recognition API
speech-recognition.description: Method to provide speech input in a web browser.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to some attributes missing.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox currently has a `media.webspeech.recognition.enable` flag in about:config for this, but actual support is waiting for permissions to be sorted out.
notes_by_num.3: Reported to be in development for Samsung Internet for GearVR, due Q1/2017
notes_by_num.4: Opera appears to have support for the `SpeechRecognition` API but no events for it appear to fire.

speech-synthesis.title: Speech Synthesis API
speech-synthesis.description: A web API for controlling a text-to-speech output.
speech-synthesis.notes: Samsung Internet for GearVR: In Development, release based on Chromium m53 due Q1/2017

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `media.webspeech.synth.enabled` about:config flag.
notes_by_num.2: Speech Synthesis in Chrome since version 55 stops playback after about 15 seconds on Windows 7 & 10, and Ubuntu 14.04, possibly other platforms

spellcheck-attribute.title: Spellcheck attribute
spellcheck-attribute.description: Attribute for `input`/`textarea` fields to enable/disable the browser's spellchecker.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Controlling spell checking

spellcheck-attribute.notes:
The partial support in mobile browsers results from their OS generally having built-in spell checking instead of using the wavy underline to indicate misspelled words. `spellcheck="false"` does not seem to have any effect in these browsers.

Browsers have different behavior in how they deal with spellchecking in combination with the the `lang` attribute. Generally spelling is based on the browser's language, not the language of the document.

sql-storage.title: Web SQL Database
sql-storage.description: Method of storing data client-side, allows SQLite database queries for access and manipulation
sql-storage.notes: The Web SQL Database specification is no longer being maintained and support may be dropped in future versions.

srcset.title: Srcset and sizes attributes
srcset.description: The `srcset` and `sizes` attributes on `img` (or `source`) elements allow authors to define various image resources and "hints" that assist a user agent to determine the most appropriate image source to display (e.g. high-resolution displays, small monitors, etc).

links.title: Improved support for high-resolution displays with the srcset image attribute

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference dom.image.srcset.enabled to true
notes_by_num.2: Supports the subset of the syntax for resolution switching (using the `x` descriptor), but not the full syntax that can be used with `sizes` (using the `w` descriptor).
notes_by_num.3: Intermittently displays distorted images due to bug present (see known issues)

stream.title: getUserMedia/Stream API
stream.description: Method of accessing external device data (such as a webcam video stream). Formerly this was envisioned as the <device> element.

links.title: Media Capture functionality in Microsoft Edge
getUserMedia in PWA with manifest on iOS 11

stream.notes: As of Chrome 47, the getUserMedia API cannot be called from insecure origins.

notes_by_num.1: Blink-based (and some other) browsers support an older version of the spec that does not use `srcObject`. [See Chromium issue 387740](https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=387740).
notes_by_num.2: Supports the older spec's `navigator.getUserMedia` API, not the newer `navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia` one.
notes_by_num.3: Does not work in standalone running ("installed") PWAs, `getUserMedia` returns no video input devices in `UIWebView` or `WKWebView`, but only directly in Safari.

streams.title: Streams
streams.description: Method of creating, composing, and consuming streams of data, that map efficiently to low-level I/O primitives, and allow easy composition with built-in backpressure and queuing.

notes_by_num.1: IE implements a different API than the one from WHATWG.
notes_by_num.2: Only basic read support.
notes_by_num.3: Disabled by default behind the `javascript.options.streams` and `dom.streams.enabled` flags.
notes_by_num.4: No support for BYOB ("bring your own buffer") stream readers.
notes_by_num.5: No support for `WritableStream`.
notes_by_num.6: No support for the `pipeTo` or `pipeThrough` methods

stricttransportsecurity.title: Strict Transport Security
stricttransportsecurity.description: Declare that a website is only accessible over a secure connection (HTTPS).

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Strict Transport Security

notes_by_num.1: IE 11 added support [in an update](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2015/06/09/http-strict-transport-security-comes-to-internet-explorer-11-on-windows-8-1-and-windows-7/) on June 9, 2015

style-scoped.title: Scoped CSS
style-scoped.description: Allows CSS rules to be scoped to part of the document, based on the position of the style element. The attribute has been [removed from the current specification](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/552).

links.title: Firefox bug #1291515: disable `<style scoped>` in content documents

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Enabled in Firefox through the about:config setting "layout.css.scoped-style.enabled"

subresource-integrity.title: Subresource Integrity
subresource-integrity.description: Subresource Integrity enables browsers to verify that file is delivered without unexpected manipulation.

links.title: SRI generation and browser support test

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

svg.title: SVG (basic support)
svg.description: Method of displaying basic Vector Graphics features using the embed or object elements. Refers to the SVG 1.1 spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android 3 & 4 refers to not supporting masking.
notes_by_num.2: IE9-11 desktop & mobile don't properly scale SVG files.  [Adding height, width, viewBox, and CSS rules](https://codepen.io/tomByrer/pen/qEBbzw?editors=110) seem to be the best workaround.

svg-css.title: SVG in CSS backgrounds
svg-css.description: Method of using SVG images as CSS backgrounds

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS Safari and older Safari versions refers to failing to support tiling or the background-position property.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older Firefox and Opera Mini/Mobile refers to SVG images being blurry when scaled.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Edge 15 and older refers to a lack of support for SVG data URIs. [see bug](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/6274479/)

svg-filters.title: SVG filters
svg-filters.description: Method of using Photoshop-like effects on SVG objects including blurring and color manipulation.

svg-fonts.title: SVG fonts
svg-fonts.description: Method of using fonts defined as SVG shapes. Removed from [SVG 2.0](https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/changes.html#fonts) and considered as a deprecated feature with support being removed from browsers.

links.title: Blog post on usage for iPad

notes_by_num.1: Chrome 38 and newer support SVG fonts only on Windows Vista and XP.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Opera Mini in SVG images only, not in HTML.

svg-fragment.title: SVG fragment identifiers
svg-fragment.description: Method of displaying only a part of an SVG image by defining a view ID or view box dimensions as the file's fragment identifier.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to support inside `` but not as CSS `background-image`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to lack of external fragments support

svg-html.title: SVG effects for HTML
svg-html.description: Method of using SVG transforms, filters, etc on HTML elements using either CSS or the foreignObject element

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Other content in SVG
MDN Web Docs - Applying SVG effects

svg-html.notes: Partial support refers to lack of filter support or buggy result from effects. A [CSS Filter Effects](https://www.w3.org/TR/filter-effects/) specification is in the works that would replace this method.

notes_by_num.1: IE11 and below do not support `<foreignObject>`.
notes_by_num.2: IE and Edge do not support applying SVG filter effects to HTML elements using CSS. [Bug Report](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/6618695/)

svg-html5.title: Inline SVG in HTML5
svg-html5.description: Method of using SVG tags directly in HTML documents. Requires HTML5 parser.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CSS transforms on SVG elements (transform attribute can be used instead)

svg-img.title: SVG in HTML img element
svg-img.description: Method of displaying SVG images in HTML using .

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting embedded images (data URIs) inside the SVG.

svg-smil.title: SVG SMIL animation
svg-smil.description: Method of using animation elements to animate SVG images

links.title: MDN Web Docs - animation with SMIL
JS library to support SMIL in SVG
Polyfill for SMIL animate events on SVG

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari versions refers to not working in HTML files or CSS background images.

tabindex-attr.title: tabindex global attribute
tabindex-attr.description: Specifies the focusability of the element and in what order (if any) it should become focused (relative to other elements) when "tabbing" through the document.
tabindex-attr.notes:
Mac OS X "Full Keyboard Access" refers to setting Keyboard→Shortcuts→Full Keyboard Access to "All controls" in the System Preferences.

"Unknown" support for mobile browsers is due to lacking a method of tabbing through fields.

notes_by_num.1: On Mac OS X, unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, `<a>` elements are not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.2: `<a>` elements are never keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`. Unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, then `<button>`s, radio buttons, and checkboxes are also not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.3: Has "previous" and "next" virtual keyboard buttons that follow tabindex order.

template.title: HTML templates
template.description: Method of declaring a portion of reusable markup that is parsed but not rendered until cloned.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support Document.importNode on templates, nested templates or elements that contain templates.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Node.cloneNode on templates, nested templates or elements that contain templates.
notes_by_num.3: Safari 6.2 has the same partial support as Safari 7.1.

template-literals.title: ES6 Template Literals (Template Strings)
template-literals.description: Template literals are string literals allowing embedded expressions. You can use multi-line strings and string interpolation features with them. Formerly known as template strings.

notes_by_num.1: Safari 12 [sometimes garbage collects](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=190756) the cached TemplateStrings used by Tagged Template Literals

text-decoration.title: text-decoration styling
text-decoration.description: Method of defining the type, style and color of lines in the text-decoration property. These can be defined as shorthand (e.g. `text-decoration: line-through dashed blue`) or as single properties (e.g. `text-decoration-color: blue`)

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

text-decoration.notes: All browsers support the CSS2 version of `text-decoration`, which matches only the `text-decoration-line` values (`underline`, etc.)

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the `text-decoration-style` property.
notes_by_num.3: Safari 8+ supports `-webkit-text-decoration-skip` with values `none` and `skip` (other values behave like `none` or `skip`)
notes_by_num.4: Partial support refers to not supporting the `text-decoration-skip` property.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support refers to `text-decoration-skip` only supporting value `objects` and `ink`.

text-emphasis.title: text-emphasis styling
text-emphasis.description: Method of using small symbols next to each glyph to emphasize a run of text, commonly used in East Asian languages. The `text-emphasis` shorthand, and its `text-emphasis-style` and `text-emphasis-color` longhands, can be used to apply marks to the text. The `text-emphasis-position` property, which inherits separately, allows setting the emphasis marks' position with respect to the text.

links.title: A javascript fallback for CSS3 emphasis mark.
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

text-emphasis.notes: Some old WebKit browsers (like Chrome 24) support `-webkit-text-emphasis`, but does not support CJK languages and is therefore considered unsupported.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to incorrect support for `-webkit-text-emphasis-position`. These browsers support `over` and `under` as values, but not the added `left` and `right` values required by the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.text-emphasis.enabled` flag

text-overflow.title: CSS3 Text-overflow
text-overflow.description: Append ellipsis when text overflows its containing element

text-size-adjust.title: CSS text-size-adjust
text-size-adjust.description: On mobile devices, the text-size-adjust CSS property allows Web authors to control if and how the text-inflating algorithm is applied to the textual content of the element it is applied to.

notes_by_num.1: If the viewport size is set using a `<meta>` element, the `-ms-text-size-adjust` property is ignored. See [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn793579%28v=vs.85%29.aspx)
notes_by_num.2: Old versions of WebKit-based desktop browsers (Chrome<27, Safari<6) [suffer from a bug](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=56543) where if `-webkit-text-size-adjust` is explicitly set to `none`, instead of ignoring the property, the browsers will prevent the user from zooming in or out on the webpage.

text-stroke.title: CSS text-stroke and text-fill
text-stroke.description: Method of declaring the outline (stroke) width and color for text.
text-stroke.notes: Does not yet appear in any W3C specification. Was briefly included in a spec as the "text-outline" property, but this was removed.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox & Edge specifically only support the `-webkit-text-stroke` property (not using `-moz-` or `-ms-` prefix)
notes_by_num.2: Requires the `layout.css.prefixes.webkit` flag to be enabled.

textcontent.title: Node.textContent
textcontent.description: DOM Node property representing the text content of a node and its descendants
textcontent.notes: `Node.textContent` is somewhat similar to, but has important differences from, [`Node.innerText`](https://caniuse.com/#feat=innertext).

textencoder.title: TextEncoder & TextDecoder
textencoder.description: `TextEncoder` encodes a JavaScript string into bytes using the UTF-8 encoding and returns the resulting `Uint8Array` of those bytes. `TextDecoder` does the reverse.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit Bug 160653 - Support TextEncoder & TextDecoder APIs

notes_by_num.1: Not available in Web Workers in Firefox 19.

tls1-1.title: TLS 1.1
tls1-1.description: Version 1.1 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol.

links.title: Modernizing Transport Security - Google Security Blog
Modernizing TLS connections in Microsoft Edge and Internet Explorer 11 - Microsoft Windows Blog
Removing Old Versions of TLS - Mozilla Security Blog
Deprecation of Legacy TLS 1.0 and 1.1 Versions - WebKit Blog

tls1-1.notes: TLS 1.0 & 1.1 are deprecated in Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Internet Explorer 11, & Safari. Support will be removed in March 2020.

tls1-2.title: TLS 1.2
tls1-2.description: Version 1.2 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Allows for data/message confidentiality, and message authentication codes for message integrity and as a by-product message authentication.

tls1-3.title: TLS 1.3
tls1-3.description: Version 1.3 (the latest one) of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Removes weaker elliptic curves and hash functions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to supporting a draft of the TLS 1.3 specification, not the final version.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the `security.tls.version.max` pref to "4" in `about:config`.
notes_by_num.3: Supports a draft of the TLS 1.3 specification, not the final version.
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled in Chrome and Opera via the `#tls13-variant` flag in `chrome://flags` or `opera://flags`.
notes_by_num.5: Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to macOS 10.14 Mojave and later.

touch.title: Touch events
touch.description: Method of registering when, where and how the interface is touched, for devices with a touch screen. These DOM events are similar to mousedown, mousemove, etc.

links.title: Internet Explorer's gesture and touch implementation.
Touch polyfill for supporting touch events on Internet Explorer

touch.notes:
Internet Explorer implements Pointer Events specification which supports more input devices than Touch Events one.

There is a library on GitHub that is working toward bringing W3C touch events to IE 10 and 11: https://github.com/CamHenlin/TouchPolyfill 

Removed support in Firefox refers to desktop Firefox only.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.w3c_touch_events.enabled flag (disabled by default for site compatibility reasons)
notes_by_num.2: Supported on IE11 Mobile for phones with "[Windows Phone 8.1 Update](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2014/07/31/the-mobile-web-should-just-work-for-everyone.aspx)"
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Edge using the "Enable touch events" flag under `about:flags`

transforms2d.title: CSS3 2D Transforms
transforms2d.description: Method of transforming an element including rotating, scaling, etc. Includes support for `transform` as well as `transform-origin` properties.
transforms2d.notes: The scale transform can be emulated in IE < 9 using Microsoft's "zoom" extension, others are (not easily) possible using the MS Matrix filter

notes_by_num.1: Does not support CSS transforms on SVG elements (transform attribute can be used instead)

transforms3d.title: CSS3 3D Transforms
transforms3d.description: Method of transforming an element in the third dimension using the `transform` property. Includes support for the `perspective` property to set the perspective in z-space and the `backface-visibility` property to toggle display of the reverse side of a 3D-transformed element.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE refers to not supporting [the transform-style: preserve-3d property](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/hh673529%28v=vs.85%29.aspx#the_ms_transform_style_property). This prevents nesting 3D transformed elements.
notes_by_num.2: Safari 9, 10, 11, & 12 are reported to still require a prefix for the related `backface-visibility` property.

ttf.title: TTF/OTF - TrueType and OpenType font support
ttf.description: Support for the TrueType (.ttf) and OpenType (.otf) outline font formats in @font-face.

links.title: What is the status of TTF support in Internet Explorer?

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9+ refers to the fonts only working [when set to be "installable"](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ie/archive/2010/07/15/the-css-corner-better-web-typography-for-better-design.aspx). Support for this is tracked [here](https://status.modern.ie/crossdomainfontloading).

typedarrays.title: Typed Arrays
typedarrays.description: JavaScript typed arrays provide a mechanism for accessing raw binary data much more efficiently. Includes: `Int8Array`, `Uint8Array`, `Uint8ClampedArray`, `Int16Array`, `Uint16Array`, `Int32Array`, `Uint32Array`, `Float32Array` & `Float64Array`

notes_by_num.1: IE10 (and IE 10&11 mobile) does not support `Uint8ClampedArray`

u2f.title: FIDO U2F API
u2f.description: JavaScript API to interact with Universal Second Factor (U2F) devices. This allows users to log into sites more securely using two-factor authentication with a USB dongle.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "FIDO U2F (Universal 2nd Factor)" Chrome extension
notes_by_num.2: Support can be enabled with the "security.webauth.u2f" flag

unhandledrejection.title: unhandledrejection/rejectionhandled events
unhandledrejection.description: The `unhandledrejection` event is fired when a Promise is rejected but there is no rejection handler to deal with the rejection. The `rejectionhandled` event is fired when a Promise is rejected, and after the rejection is handled by the promise's rejection handling code.

upgradeinsecurerequests.title: Upgrade Insecure Requests
upgradeinsecurerequests.description: Declare that browsers should transparently upgrade HTTP resources on a website to HTTPS.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Upgrade Insecure Requests

upgradeinsecurerequests.notes: The HTTP header is `Content-Security-Policy: upgrade-insecure-requests`. Alternatively, the HTML tag is `<meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="upgrade-insecure-requests">`.

url.title: URL API
url.description: API to retrieve the various parts that make up a given URL from a given URL string.

notes_by_num.1: Allows objects to be created via `URL` constructor, but instances do not have the expected url properties.

urlsearchparams.title: URLSearchParams
urlsearchparams.description: The URLSearchParams interface defines utility methods to work with the query string of a URL.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting `entries()`, `keys()`, `values()`, and `for...of`.

use-strict.title: ECMAScript 5 Strict Mode
use-strict.description: Method of placing code in a "strict" operating context.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older Safari refers to strict mode still accepting a lot of JS that should be considered invalid.

user-select-none.title: CSS user-select: none
user-select-none.description: Method of preventing text/element selection using CSS.

user-timing.title: User Timing API
user-timing.description: Method to help web developers measure the performance of their applications by giving them access to high precision timestamps.

variable-fonts.title: Variable fonts
variable-fonts.description: OpenType font settings that allows a single font file to behave like multiple fonts: it can contain all the allowed variations in width, weight, slant, optical size, or any other exposed axes of variation as defined by the font designer. Variations can be applied via the `font-variation-settings` property.

links.title: Axis-Praxs - Tool & info on variable fonts
How to use variable fonts in the real world

notes_by_num.1: Works with Experimental Web Platform features enabled
notes_by_num.2:
Requires MacOS 10.12+ and the following about:config flags to be enabled:
`layout.css.font-variations.enabled`,
`gfx.downloadable_fonts.keep_variation_tables`
notes_by_num.3: Requires MacOS 10.13+
notes_by_num.4: Does not support the `font-weight` and `font-stretch` properties.
notes_by_num.5: Does not support `format('truetype-variations')`, `format('woff-variations')`, `format('woff2-variations')`

variable-fonts.keywords: variable fonts, variation fonts, font variations

vibration.title: Vibration API
vibration.description: Method to access the vibration mechanism of the hosting device.

video.title: Video element
video.description: Method of playing videos on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: `currentSrc`, `currentTime`, `paused`, `playbackRate`, `buffered`, `duration`, `played`, `seekable`, `ended`, `autoplay`, `loop`, `controls`, `volume` & `muted`

links.title: Video on the Web - includes info on Android support

video.notes: Different browsers have support for different video formats, see sub-features for details.

notes_by_num.1: The Android browser (before 2.3) requires [specific handling](http://www.broken-links.com/2010/07/08/making-html5-video-work-on-android-phones/) to run the video element.
notes_by_num.2: Old Firefox versions were missing support for some properties: `loop` was added in v11, `played` in v15, `playbackRate` in v20.
notes_by_num.3: Ignores the `autoplay` attribute by default, though autoplay behavior can be [enabled by users](https://webkit.org/blog/7734/auto-play-policy-changes-for-macos/)

videotracks.title: Video Tracks
videotracks.description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple video tracks. Useful for providing sign language tracks, burnt-in captions or subtitles, alternative camera angles, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Chrome and Opera by enabling "enable-experimental-web-platform-features" in chrome:flags

viewport-units.title: Viewport units: vw, vh, vmin, vmax
viewport-units.description: Length units representing a percentage of the current viewport dimensions: width (vw), height (vh), the smaller of the two (vmin), or the larger of the two (vmax).

links.title: Buggyfill - Polyfill that fixes buggy support
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE9 refers to supporting "vm" instead of "vmin".
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting the "vmax" unit.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in iOS7 is due to buggy behavior of the "vh" unit (see workarounds: [1](https://gist.github.com/pburtchaell/e702f441ba9b3f76f587), [2](https://gist.github.com/BenMorel/e9e34c08360ebbbd0634)).

wai-aria.title: WAI-ARIA Accessibility features
wai-aria.description: Method of providing ways for people with disabilities to use dynamic web content and web applications.
wai-aria.notes: Support for ARIA is rather complex and currently is not fully supported in any browser. For detailed information on partial support see the [ARIA 1.0 Implementation Report](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/1.0/CR/implementation-report)

wasm.title: WebAssembly
wasm.description: WebAssembly or "wasm" is a new portable, size- and load-time-efficient format suitable for compilation to the web.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `javascript.options.wasm` in `about:config`
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `#enable-webassembly` flag
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled via the Experimental JavaScript Features flag
notes_by_num.4: Disabled for Firefox 52 ESR
notes_by_num.5: Available in Samsung Internet 7 beta

wav.title: Wav audio format
wav.description: Waveform Audio File Format, aka WAV or WAVE, a typically uncompressed audio format.
wav.notes: Support refers to this format's use in the `audio` element, not other conditions.

wbr-element.title: wbr (word break opportunity) element
wbr-element.description: Represents an extra place where a line of text may optionally be broken.

web-animation.title: Web Animations API
web-animation.description: Lets you create animations that are run in the browser, as well as inspect and manipulate animations created through declarative means like CSS.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()` and [playback control of AnimationPlayer](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5633748733263872)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox is detailed in [Are we animated yet?](https://birtles.github.io/areweanimatedyet/)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

web-app-manifest.title: Web App Manifest
web-app-manifest.description: The web app manifest provides information about an application (such as name, author, icon, and description) in a JSON file, which browsers can use to give richer offline experiences.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Web App Manifest
PWACompat (polyfill) - A library that brings the Web App Manifest to non-compliant browsers

notes_by_num.1: The installation events, `appinstalled` and `beforeinstallprompt`, are not supported.
notes_by_num.2: The installation events, `appinstalled` and `beforeinstallprompt`, are not supported on all platforms.
notes_by_num.3: The manifest may be used to list apps in the Microsoft Store, which will use Edge as a back-end. However, Edge does not directly implement the Manifest spec.

web-bluetooth.title: Web Bluetooth
web-bluetooth.description: Allows web sites to communicate over GATT with nearby user-selected Bluetooth devices in a secure and privacy-preserving way.

notes_by_num.1: Available by enabling the "Web Bluetooth" experimental flag in `about:flags`. Currently support [varies by OS](https://github.com/WebBluetoothCG/web-bluetooth/blob/gh-pages/implementation-status.md)
notes_by_num.2: Only in Opera Mobile
notes_by_num.3: Available in [Origin Trials](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/07/interact-with-ble-devices-on-the-web#available-for-origin-trials) for Chrome OS, Android M, and Mac
notes_by_num.4: Currently support [varies by OS](https://github.com/WebBluetoothCG/web-bluetooth/blob/gh-pages/implementation-status.md)

web-share.title: Web Share API
web-share.description: A way to allow websites to invoke the native sharing capabilities of the host platform

links.title: Web Share API brings the native sharing capabilities to the browser
Mozilla bug #1312422: Consider experimental support for Web Share API

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to feature only being available for sites opting into the [origin trial](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/OriginTrials/blob/gh-pages/developer-guide.md)
notes_by_num.2: Implemented old [Web Intents](https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/web-intents/raw-file/tip/spec/Overview-respec.html)
notes_by_num.3: Android [intent://](https://developer.chrome.com/multidevice/android/intents) URLs can be used instead.

webauthn.title: Web Authentication API
webauthn.description: The Web Authentication API is an extension of the Credential Management API that enables strong authentication with public key cryptography, enabling password-less authentication and / or secure second-factor authentication without SMS texts.

links.title: Web Authentication on MDN Web Docs

notes_by_num.1:
Can be enabled at `about:flags`

Edge 13 used an earlier draft syntax. As of Edge 14 the implementation is prefixed and based on the FIDO 2.0 Web APIs.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled using the Develop > Experimental Features menu. Currently supports USB-based CTAP & CTAP2 HID devices.

webgl.title: WebGL - 3D Canvas graphics
webgl.description: Method of generating dynamic 3D graphics using JavaScript, accelerated through hardware
webgl.notes:
WebGL support is dependent on GPU support and may not be available on older devices. This is due to the additional requirement for users to have [up to date video drivers](http://www.khronos.org/webgl/wiki/BlacklistsAndWhitelists).

Note that WebGL is part of the [Khronos Group](http://www.khronos.org/webgl/), not the W3C.

notes_by_num.1: WebGL context is accessed from "experimental-webgl" rather than "webgl"

webgl2.title: WebGL 2.0
webgl2.description: Next version of WebGL. Based on OpenGL ES 3.0.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference webgl.enable-prototype-webgl2 to true
notes_by_num.2: WebGL2 context is accessed from "experimental-webgl2" rather than "webgl2"
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Chrome by passing the "--enable-unsafe-es3-apis" flag when starting the browser through the command line
notes_by_num.4: Has an option to enable via the "Experimental Features" developer menu but fails 77% of the WebGL2 conformance tests make it nearly unusable and has not seen any development activity in over 3 years
notes_by_num.5: Enabled by default for Nightly and Dev Edition

webm.title: WebM video format
webm.description: Multimedia format designed to provide a royalty-free, high-quality open video compression format for use with HTML5 video. WebM supports the video codec VP8 and VP9.

links.title: Info on supporting WebM in Safari

webm.notes: Will work in IE9+ and Safari/MacOSX provided the user has the WebM codecs installed. Partial support indicates that at least one codec is supported but not all. MS Edge supports VP9 from MSE sources, also progressive sources are not supported by Edge.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports [VP8 used in WebRTC.](https://webkit.org/blog/8672/on-the-road-to-webrtc-1-0-including-vp8/)

webp.title: WebP image format
webp.description: Image format that supports lossy and lossless compression, as well as animation and alpha transparency.

links.title: Polyfill for browsers with WebM support
Polyfill for browsers with or without WebM support (i.e. IE6-IE9, Safari/iOS version 6.1 and below; Firefox versions 24 and bel
Official website FAQ - Which web browsers natively support WebP?
Polyfill for browsers with or without WebM support
Polyfill for browsers with WebM support

webp.notes: [Safari](https://www.cnet.com/news/apple-ios-macos-tests-googles-webp-graphics-to-speed-up-web) is experimenting with supporting WebP images.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting lossless, alpha and animated WebP images.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting animated WebP images.

websockets.title: Web Sockets
websockets.description: Bidirectional communication technology for web apps
websockets.notes: Reported to be supported in some Android 4.x browsers, including Sony Xperia S, Sony TX and HTC.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in older browsers refers to the websockets implementation using an older version of the protocol and/or the implementation being disabled by default (due to security issues with the older protocol).
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older browsers refers to lacking support for binary data.

webusb.title: WebUSB
webusb.description: Allows communication with devices via USB (Universal Serial Bus).

webvr.title: WebXR API
webvr.description: API for accessing virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) devices, including sensors and head-mounted displays.

links.title: Chrome Platform Status for WebXR Device API

webvr.notes: For a WebVR experience a head mounted display (VR HMD) is required.

notes_by_num.1: Available and enabled by default only in Firefox Windows. Enabled in Nightly for iOS. Work in progress for GNU/Linux.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled behind the WebVR & "Gamepad Extensions" flags under `chrome://flags`. Currently builds use an older version of the (still changing) specification and supports only the Oculus Rift and the HTC vive on Windows VR-ready computers.
notes_by_num.3: [In development](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2016/09/09/webvr-in-development-edge/#3lMW05DTZXbXcK46.97) in the latest Edge builds and supports only [Windows Mixed Reality](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/mixed-reality).
notes_by_num.4: Supports only Samsung Galaxy devices with the Samsung Gear VR
notes_by_num.5: Supports only Google Daydream on [daydream-ready devices](https://vr.google.com/daydream/smartphonevr/phones/) and Google Cardboards

webvtt.title: WebVTT - Web Video Text Tracks
webvtt.description: Format for marking up text captions for multimedia resources.

links.title: Getting Started With the Track Element
An Introduction to WebVTT and track

webvtt.notes: WebVTT must be used with the <track> element.

notes_by_num.1: Firefox currently lacks support for the `::cue` pseudo-element. [See bug #865395.](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=865395)

webworkers.title: Web Workers
webworkers.description: Method of running scripts in the background, isolated from the web page

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Using Web Workers

will-change.title: CSS will-change property
will-change.description: Method of optimizing animations by informing the browser which elements will change and what properties will change.

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.will-change.enabled` flag

woff.title: WOFF - Web Open Font Format
woff.description: Compressed TrueType/OpenType font that contains information about the font's source.

notes_by_num.1: Reported to be supported in some modified versions of the Android 4.0 browser.

woff2.title: WOFF 2.0 - Web Open Font Format
woff2.description: TrueType/OpenType font that provides better compression than WOFF 1.0.

notes_by_num.1: Supported only on Safari for Mac OS Sierra, not El Capitan & older.

word-break.title: CSS3 word-break
word-break.description: Property to prevent or allow words to be broken over multiple lines between letters.
word-break.notes:
Partial support refers to supporting the `break-all` value, but not the `keep-all` value.

Chrome, Safari and other WebKit/Blink browsers also support the unofficial `break-word` value which is treated like `word-wrap: break-word`.

wordwrap.title: CSS3 Overflow-wrap
wordwrap.description: Allows lines to be broken within words if an otherwise unbreakable string is too long to fit. Currently mostly supported using the `word-wrap` property.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

wordwrap.notes: Partial support refers to requiring the legacy name "word-wrap" (rather than "overflow-wrap") to work.

x-doc-messaging.title: Cross-document messaging
x-doc-messaging.description: Method of sending information from a page on one domain to a page on a different one (using postMessage)

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only working in frames/iframes (not other tabs/windows). Also, objects cannot be sent using postMessage.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to [limitations in certain conditions](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16226924/is-cross-origin-postmessage-broken-in-ie10).

x-frame-options.title: X-Frame-Options HTTP header
x-frame-options.description: An HTTP header which indicates whether the browser should allow the webpage to be displayed in a frame within another webpage. Used as a defense against clickjacking attacks.

links.title: IE8 Security Part VII: ClickJacking Defenses - IEBlog

x-frame-options.notes:
Partial support refers to not supporting the `ALLOW-FROM` option.
The `X-Frame-Options` header has been obsoleted by [the `frame-ancestors` directive](https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP2/#directive-frame-ancestors) from Content Security Policy Level 2.

xhr2.title: XMLHttpRequest advanced features
xhr2.description: Adds more functionality to XHR (aka AJAX) requests like file uploads, transfer progress information and the ability to send form data. Previously known as [XMLHttpRequest Level 2](https://www.w3.org/TR/2012/WD-XMLHttpRequest-20120117/), these features now appear simply in the XMLHttpRequest spec.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not supporting `json` as `responseType`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to not supporting `.timeout` and `.ontimeout`
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to not supporting `blob` as `responseType`

xhtml.title: XHTML served as application/xhtml+xml
xhtml.description: A strict form of HTML, and allows embedding of other XML languages
xhtml.notes: The XHTML syntax is very close to HTML, and thus is almost always ([incorrectly](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/XHTML#MIME_type_versus_DOCTYPE)) served as text/html on the web.

xhtmlsmil.title: XHTML+SMIL animation
xhtmlsmil.description: Method of using SMIL animation in web pages
xhtmlsmil.notes: Internet Explorer supports the W3C proposal HTML+TIME, which is largely the same as XHTML+SMIL

xml-serializer.title: DOM Parsing and Serialization
xml-serializer.description: Various DOM parsing and serializing functions, specifically `DOMParser`, `XMLSerializer`, `innerHTML`, `outerHTML` and `insertAdjacentHTML`.

links.title: Comparing Document Position by John Resig

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking support for `parseFromString` on the DOMParser.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting only `innerHTML`.
notes_by_num.3: Partial support refers to supporting only `innerHTML` and `insertAdjacentHTML`.
